choices.A: Layer 1 is down on the controller.
choices.C: Nothing, the PRI is sending keepalives.
choices.D: Layer 2 is down on the controller.
choices.B: PRI does not have an IP address configured on the interface.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If Layer 2 is stable, the router and switch must begin to synchronize with each other. The Set Asynchronous Balanced Mode Extended (SABME) message appears on the display. This message indicates that Layer 2 tries to initialize with the other side. Either side can send the message and try to initialize with the other side. If the router receives the SABME message, it must send back an Unnumbered Acknowledge frame (UAf).
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wan/t1-e1-t3-e3/8131-T1-pri.html

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Given this "debug isdn q921" output, what is the problem with the PRI?
An administrator is trying to change the default LINECODE for a voice ISDN T1 PRI. Which command makes this change?

discussion.content: should be B default is b8zs

D is correct. Question is changing from default (which is AMI) for T1 line. So the correct answer is b8zs. hdb3 is for E1.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/voice/cminterop/configuration/guide/12_4t/vc_12_4t_book/vc_mgcp_t1cas.html

Selected Answer: B
Read and understand the question. Correct answer is B
As per the guide we configure following linecodes:
ami—Specifies Alternate Mark Inversion (AMI) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 and E1 controllers.
b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
hdb3—Specifies high-density binary 3 (HDB3) as the linecode type. Valid for E1 controller only. This is the default for E1 lines.
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/ncs4200/configuration/guide/tdm/tdm-cfg-t1-e1-ncs4200-book.html

A - no esf is framing not linecode
B - fine it's non default framing possible to configure on T1
C - no because hdb3 is for E1 only
D - no because b8zs is default for T1

Selected Answer: B
should be B default is b8zs
B8ZS is the default linecode for T1. and changing from defualt

Selected Answer: B
This snippet was taken from the link below:
"ami—Specifies Alternate Mark Inversion (AMI) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 and E1 controllers.
b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
hdb3—Specifies high-density binary 3 (HDB3) as the linecode type. Valid for E1 controller only. This is the default for E1 lines."

So basically, for T1: default is b8zs (so the anser to this question should be AMI as hdb3 is only valid for E1)

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/ncs4200/configuration/guide/tdm/tdm-cfg-t1-e1-ncs4200-book.html#:~:text=B8ZS%20is%20the%20default%20linecode%20for%20T1.

Selected Answer: D
Per the CLCOR book AMI is default so correct answer is B8ZS.
Update its B - AMI
I have checked the same question on questions provided by friend who have already passed the exam and its A - AMI

Selected Answer: B
https://content.cisco.com/chapter.sjs?uri=/searchable/chapter/www.cisco.com/content/en/us/td/docs/switches/metro/me3600x_3800x/software/release/15-2_4_S/chassis/configuration/guide/3600x_24cxscg/sw_T1-E1.html.xml

Selects the linecode type.
ami—Specifies Alternate Mark Inversion (AMI) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 and E1 controllers.
b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
hdb3—Specifies high-density binary 3 (HDB3) as the linecode type. Valid for E1 controller only. This is the default for E1 lines.
esf – framing (not linecode)

Because Q asks for changing the default linecode (for T1), correct answer is B

Per Cisco: t1—Specifies T1 connectivity of 1.536 Mbps. B8ZS is the default line code for T1.

If B8ZS is the default, then the linecode needs to be set to AMI manually. Therefore B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/ncs4200/configuration/guide/tdm/tdm-cfg-t1-e1-ncs4200-book.html
Selects the linecode type.

ami—Specifies Alternate Mark Inversion (AMI) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 and E1 controllers.
b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
hdb3—Specifies high-density binary 3 (HDB3) as the linecode type. Valid for E1 controller only. This is the default for E1 lines.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. Default for T1s is AMI (Alternate Mark Inversion), Default for E1s is hdb3 (High Density Bipolar 3). b8zs (Bipolar with eight-zero substitution) is a modified AMI for North American States. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Services_Digital_Network. According to Cisco, AMI is already the default for T1s so to change it, the only other option is b8zs. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/voice/cminterop/configuration/guide/12_4t/vc_12_4t_book/vc_mgcp_t1cas.html

ami: Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines.

b8zs: B8ZS, valid for T1 controllers only.

hdb3: High-density bipolar 3 (hdb3), valid for E1 controllers only. Default for E1 lines

correct is D

The keywords and descriptions are as follows:
- ami: Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines.
- b8zs: B8ZS, valid for T1 controllers only.
- hdb3: High-density bipolar 3 (hdb3), valid for E1 controllers only. Default for E1 lines.

i feel like half the people claim AMI is default and half that b8zs is default.

this shouldnt be that hard to verify, on an E1 device i can choose between hdb3 and AMI, when i configure AMI it shows up in the running conf, when i configure hdb3 it doesnt, so on E1 at least hdb3 is default. sadly i dont have a T1 card to verify myself.

Selected Answer: D
linecode b8zs
default for t1 is ami

Selected Answer: D
Another tricky question. I have look at many references, we should remember the question asked for ISDN T1, and not other T1. And in most of ISDN document you will see the command “linecode b8zs”, which is trying to change the default ami to b8zs.
D is correct answer.
correct is ami; the default is b8zs, but the default should be changed

From:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/voice/isdn/configuration/15-mt/vi-15-mt-book/vi-isdn-vi-cfg.html

 ami --Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines.
 b8zs --B8ZS, valid for T1 controllers only.
 hdb3 --High-density bipolar 3 (hdb3), valid for E1 controllers only. Default for E1 lines.

I'm seeing a lot of confusion on this topic mostly because some cisco switches namely 3600 manual says b8zs is the default however the Cisco ISDN Configuration guide version 15 dated Feb 2019 says that AMI is the default for T1. I'm gonna stick with B8zs and go off the ISDN configuration guide and not the manual for that one switch.

Correct Ans: "linecode b8zs"


AMI is default for T1,

Sets the line-encoding method to match that of your telephone-company service provider. Keywords are as follows:

ami --Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines.

b8zs --B8ZS, valid for T1 controllers only.

hdb3 --High-density bipolar 3 (hdb3), valid for E1 controllers only. Default for E1 lines.

"B" is right:
• ami—Specifies Alternate Mark Inversion (AMI) as the linecode
type. Valid for T1 and E1 controllers.
• b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode
type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
• hdb3—Specifies high-density binary 3 (HDB3) as the linecode type.
Valid for E1 controller only. This is the default for E1 lines.

ami --Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines

Answer should be B. 
the default linecode on T1 PRI is b8zs. changing it to ami is changing the default linecode.

Looking at this Logically, we are looking at linecode for T1 only

esf - not valid, This is a framing command for extended super frame (definitely incorrect)
ami - valid for T1&E1 (possible correct)
hbd3 - valid for E1 only (definitely incorrect)
b8zs - valid for T1 only (possible correct)

From this our only possible answers are ami or b8zs

This link, 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/asr903/software/guide/chassis/xe-3s/b_Config_Guide_fullbook/b_Config_Guide_fullbook_chapter_01010.pdf
Page 4 Configuration step 4 states that
 b8zs—Specifies binary 8-zero substitution (B8ZS) as the linecode
type. Valid for T1 controller only. This is the default for T1 lines.
However
This link
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/voice/isdn/configuration/15-mt/vi-15-mt-book/vi-isdn-vi-cfg.html
States tin step 7 that
ami --Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines.

comments.content:
However Looking at the CLCOR book (PAGE 535) it states that AMI is default for T1 lines,

so I would select option D b8zs as being the command to CHANGE the default as it is the only other valid option.

I believe the first link is referring to T1 and data rather than voice, However I am treating the book, and Jason Ball as being correct.

discussion.content: should be D I think as ami --Alternate mark inversion (AMI), valid for T1 or E1 controllers. Default for T1 lines. anhttps://www.examtopics.com/exams/cisco/350-801/view/6/#d it says T1 line and b8zs --B8ZS, valid for T1 controllers only.

In T1 configuration ,default is b8zs (alternate mark inversion) .
To change the default value ,the next option is AMI .
hdb3 is for E1.
esf is not line code, it is framing .

So the correct answer is "linecode ami" which is the Option B.

Answer is D.
T1 default linecode is b8zs (Non ISDN Voice)
ISDN Voice T1 default line code is ami

questions.question_text:
Due to provider requirements, outgoing calls from the Enterprise to the PSTN must start with channel 1.
Which ISDN command changes the channel selection on IOS to meet this requirement?

discussion.content: D is correct

comments.content:
Yes, A and C, are wrong, you wont have layer 1 up if they are true.
and B clock problems, cant turn down the layer 2 service.

Symptoms :- ISDN layer 1 is active and Layer 2 going up and down with error “TEI_ASSIGNED”

There could be following missing command under signaling interface at Telco end if they are using Cisco Gateway.

Furthermore, the show isdn status command displays a summary of the current status. Therefore, Layer 2 can bounce up and down even though it indicates a MULTIPLE_FRAME_ESTABLISHED state. It is needed to use the debug isdn q921 command to ensure that Layer 2 is stable. This situation can be leveraged by a incorrect clock, however, as we do not have debug isdn q921, we are forced to assume that clock is correct and no slip erros. 
Please refer to (it is amazing this document):
Troubleshoot T1 PPRI
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wan/t1-e1-t3-e3/8131-T1-pri.pdf

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A. and C. do not have sense.
B, is talking about a possibility of a intermittent service, it could be swinging between up and down. These errors can be viewed in the show controllers T1, however, the Layer 2 can be viewed in state MULTIPLE_FRAME_ESTABLISHED even though these slips errors. 
D. could be the best answer, simply on side can not understand the frames from the other side, mean while while one side is sending SABME's like crazy and not receiving anything from the other side that could be solved with a correct configuration. I do not know if the problem is the framing or a bad configuration in the Serial interface (isdn protocol-emulate command), because it is stupid to be guessing without without having debug isdn q921and show controller t1 outputs, however, the only reason about the problem is a configuration issue, and just the answer D shows us "configured incorrectly". Something is configured incorrectly, without a doubt.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, Farming needs to be fixed, 
Slips are the result of B.

Selected Answer: B
D is the answer, B would be right if you had slips

comments.content: Changed my mind it is D

discussion.content:
